skill.name: biopython
skill.description: Comprehensive molecular biology toolkit. Use for sequence manipulation, file parsing (FASTA/GenBank/PDB), phylogenetics, and programmatic NCBI/PubMed access (Bio.Entrez). Best for batch processing, custom bioinformatics pipelines, BLAST automation. For quick lookups use gget; for multi-service integration use bioservices.
skill.summary: Bioinformatics toolkit for sequence analysis, database access, BLAST, structural biology, and phylogenetics using Biopython.
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: Documentation-only skill containing markdown files with Biopython code examples. All 525 static findings are false positives caused by the scanner misinterpreting markdown code block delimiters as shell commands and Biopython module names as cryptographic algorithms. This is a legitimate scientific documentation skill with no executable code.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [MEDIUM] external_commands: Ruby/shell backtick execution (415 locations across all .md files)
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Markdown code block delimiters (triple backticks ```) are being misinterpreted as shell backtick execution. These are documentation files with Python code examples, not executable Ruby/shell scripts. No actual command execution exists in this skill.

Biopython module names and algorithm references in documentation (Bio.Align, substitution matrices, hashing functions) are not cryptographic algorithms. These are legitimate bioinformatics methods for sequence alignment and analysis.

Documentation examples showing SeqIO file operations are educational content explaining how to read/write FASTA/GenBank files. These are documentation patterns, not actual file operations that could cause harm.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [LOW] network: Python HTTP libraries and Hardcoded URLs
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: URLs point to biopython.org documentation (lines 409-412 in SKILL.md). Entrez API usage examples demonstrate legitimate NCBI database access patterns for bioinformatics research.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [HIGH] env_access: Generic API/secret keys (lines 59, 26 in databases.md)
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: Documentation shows placeholder examples like 'your_api_key_here' and 'your.email@example.com' - standard practice for teaching API configuration. No real credentials are present. These examples teach proper NCBI Entrez authentication.
Documentation about file parsing, sequence analysis, and structure examination describes legitimate bioinformatics operations. No reconnaissance or system information gathering patterns exist.

static_findings_evaluation.finding: [CRITICAL] obfuscation: DANGEROUS COMBINATION - Code execution + Network + Credential access
static_findings_evaluation.reasoning: This 'dangerous' pattern represents standard bioinformatics workflows. Documentation shows code examples that access NCBI databases with authentication - exactly what Biopython is designed for. No malicious intent or obfuscation exists.

content.user_title: Work with biological sequences and NCBI databases
content.value_statement: This skill provides access to Biopython, a comprehensive bioinformatics library. Use it to analyze DNA, RNA, and protein sequences, access NCBI databases, run BLAST searches, and perform structural bioinformatics tasks.
actual_capabilities: Read and write biological sequence files in FASTA, GenBank, FASTQ, and PDB formats
Access NCBI databases programmatically via Entrez (PubMed, GenBank, Protein)
Run BLAST searches and parse results using Bio.Blast
Perform pairwise and multiple sequence alignments
Analyze protein 3D structures from PDB files
Build and manipulate phylogenetic trees with Bio.Phylo
limitations: Does not provide pre-installed alignment tools (MUSCLE, Clustal)
Does not include local BLAST database functionality
Requires internet connection for NCBI database access
Does not perform de novo genome assembly

use_cases.title: Batch sequence processing
use_cases.description: Process thousands of sequences from FASTA files, calculate GC content, and extract features.

use_cases.title: Database literature search
use_cases.description: Search PubMed and retrieve GenBank records for genes and proteins of interest.

use_cases.title: Protein structure analysis
use_cases.description: Parse PDB files, calculate distances between atoms, and extract chains and residues.

prompt_templates.title: Basic sequence lookup
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to read sequences from a FASTA file and calculate the length of each sequence.

prompt_templates.title: Database search
prompt_templates.prompt: How do I search PubMed for articles about CRISPR and fetch the first 5 results?

prompt_templates.title: Alignment workflow
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a pairwise alignment between two DNA sequences and show me the alignment score.

prompt_templates.title: Complete pipeline
prompt_templates.description: Run a BLAST search, get the top hits, and fetch the matching sequences from GenBank.

output_examples.input: Read a GenBank file and extract gene information
output: â€¢ Access record.features for gene annotations
â€¢ Extract gene name from /gene qualifier: record.features[0].qualifiers['gene'][0]
â€¢ Close the file handle after processing

best_practices: Set Entrez.email before making NCBI queries to comply with their terms of service
Use API keys for higher rate limits (10 requests per second vs 3)
Process large files iteratively with generators to avoid memory issues
anti_patterns: Hardcoding API keys directly in scripts - use environment variables instead
Making repeated requests without delays - respect NCBI rate limits
Loading entire large files into memory - use streaming parsers

faq.question: How do I install Biopython?
faq.answer: Use pip install: uv pip install biopython. Requires Python 3 and NumPy.

faq.question: What sequence formats are supported?
faq.answer: FASTA, GenBank, FASTQ, EMBL, PDB, mmCIF, and many more via Bio.SeqIO.

faq.question: How do I access NCBI databases?
faq.answer: Use Bio.Entrez module with esearch, efetch, esummary functions after setting Entrez.email.

faq.question: Can I run local BLAST searches?
faq.answer: Yes, Bio.Blast supports local BLAST+ installation. Use NCBIWWW for web-based searches.

faq.question: How do I parse protein structures?
faq.answer: Use Bio.PDB.PDBParser() to read PDB files and navigate the SMCRA hierarchy.

faq.question: What is the rate limit for NCBI Entrez?
faq.answer: 3 requests per second without API key, 10 requests per second with api_key set.
